text: Who was Samuel's mother?
verseText: And in due time Hannah conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Samuel, for she said, 'I have asked for him from the LORD.' (ESV)

text: What was the name of the high priest at Shiloh when Samuel was born?
verseText: Now this man used to go up year by year from his city to worship and to sacrifice to the LORD of hosts at Shiloh, where the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were priests of the LORD. (ESV)

text: What did Hannah promise God if He gave her a son?
options: Dedicate him to the LORD's service
verseText: And she vowed a vow and said, 'O LORD of hosts, if you will indeed look on the affliction of your servant and remember me... and give to your servant a son, then I will give him to the LORD all the days of his life, and no razor shall touch his head.' (ESV)

text: Where did Samuel serve as a boy?
verseText: Samuel was ministering before the LORD, a boy clothed with a linen ephod. (ESV)

text: What were the names of Eli's wicked sons?
verseText: ...where the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were priests of the LORD. (ESV)

text: How did God call Samuel during the night?
verseText: Then the LORD called Samuel, and he said, 'Here I am!' (ESV)

text: Who captured the Ark of the Covenant from Israel?
verseText: And the ark of God was captured, and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, died. (ESV)

text: What happened to Eli when he heard the Ark was captured?
options: He fell backward, broke his neck, and died
verseText: As soon as he mentioned the ark of God, Eli fell over backward from his seat by the side of the gate, and his neck was broken and he died, for the man was old and heavy. He had judged Israel forty years. (ESV)

text: What happened to the Philistine idol Dagon when the Ark was placed beside it?
options: It fell face down and broke
verseText: And when they rose early on the morrow, behold, Dagon had fallen face downward on the ground before the ark of the LORD, and the head of Dagon and both his hands were lying cut off on the threshold. Only the trunk of Dagon was left to him. (ESV)

text: What affliction did God send upon the Philistine cities that held the Ark?
verseText: The hand of the LORD was heavy against the people of Ashdod, and he terrified and afflicted them with tumors, both Ashdod and its territory. (ESV) [Also mentioned mice in 6:4-5]

text: How did the Philistines return the Ark of the Covenant?
options: On a new cart pulled by two milk cows
verseText: Now then, take and prepare a new cart and two milk cows on which there has never come a yoke, and yoke the cows to the cart, but take their calves home, away from them. (ESV)

text: What did the people of Israel ask Samuel for?
options: A king to rule over them
verseText: and said to him, 'Behold, you are old and your sons do not walk in your ways. Now appoint for us a king to judge us like all the nations.' (ESV)

text: Who was the first king of Israel?
verseText: And Samuel said to all the people, 'Do you see him whom the LORD has chosen? There is none like him among all the people.' And all the people shouted, 'Long live the king!' (ESV)

text: What tribe was Saul from?
verseText: There was a man of Benjamin whose name was Kish... And he had a son whose name was Saul, a handsome young man. There was not a man among the people of Israel more handsome than he. (ESV)

text: What sign did Samuel give Saul after anointing him?
options: He would meet prophets prophesying and join them
verseText: After that you shall come to Gibeath-elohim... As soon as you come to the city, you will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place... prophesying. Then the Spirit of the LORD will rush upon you, and you will prophesy with them and be turned into another man. (ESV)

text: Who was Saul's son, known for his bravery and friendship with David?
verseText: One day Jonathan the son of Saul said to the young man who carried his armor, 'Come, let us go over to the Philistine garrison on the other side.' (ESV)

text: What mistake did Saul make that led Samuel to rebuke him at Gilgal?
options: He offered a burnt offering himself instead of waiting for Samuel
verseText: So Saul said, 'Bring the burnt offering here to me, and the peace offerings.' And he offered the burnt offering... And Samuel said to Saul, 'You have done foolishly. You have not kept the command of the LORD your God...' (ESV)

text: Who did God choose to be the next king after Saul?
verseText: The LORD said to Samuel, 'How long will you grieve over Saul, since I have rejected him from being king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and go. I will send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have provided for myself a king among his sons.' (ESV)

text: Who was David's father?
verseText: I will send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have provided for myself a king among his sons. (ESV)

text: What town was David from?
verseText: I will send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite... (ESV)

text: What instrument did David play for King Saul?
verseText: And whenever the harmful spirit from God was upon Saul, David took the lyre and played it with his hand. So Saul was refreshed and was well, and the harmful spirit departed from him. (ESV)

text: Who was the Philistine giant that David fought?
verseText: And there came out from the camp of the Philistines a champion named Goliath of Gath, whose height was six cubits and a span. (ESV)

text: What weapon did David use to kill Goliath?
verseText: And David put his hand in his bag and took out a stone and slung it and struck the Philistine on his forehead... So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with a stone, and struck the Philistine and killed him. (ESV)

text: Why did Saul become jealous of David?
options: The women sang, 'Saul has struck down his thousands, and David his ten thousands.'
verseText: And the women sang to one another as they celebrated, 'Saul has struck down his thousands, and David his ten thousands.' And Saul was very angry, and this saying displeased him. (ESV)

text: Which of Saul's daughters did David marry?
verseText: David arose and went, along with his men, and killed two hundred of the Philistines. And David brought their foreskins, which were given in full number to the king, that he might become the king's son-in-law. And Saul gave him his daughter Michal for a wife. (ESV)

text: How did Jonathan help David escape from Saul?
options: Warned him with coded arrow signals
verseText: In the morning Jonathan went out into the field to the appointment with David, and with him a little boy... Jonathan called after the boy and said, 'Is not the arrow beyond you?'... So Jonathan’s boy gathered up the arrows and came to his master. (ESV) [Pre-arranged signal]

text: What did David receive from the priest Ahimelech at Nob?
verseText: So the priest gave him the holy bread... Then the priest said, 'The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the Valley of Elah, behold, it is here wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you will take that, take it.' (ESV)

text: How many times did David spare Saul's life?
verseText: [Chapter 24: David cuts Saul's robe in a cave. Chapter 26: David takes Saul's spear and water jug while he sleeps.] (ESV)

text: Who was the wealthy, foolish man who insulted David and his men?
verseText: The name of the man was Nabal, and the name of his wife Abigail... The man was harsh and badly behaved... And Nabal answered David's servants, 'Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse?... Shall I take my bread and my water and my meat that I have killed for my shearers and give it to men who come from I do not know where?' (ESV)

text: How did Saul die?
options: Fell on his own sword in battle
verseText: Then Saul said to his armor-bearer, 'Draw your sword, and thrust me through with it, lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through, and mistreat me.' But his armor-bearer would not... Therefore Saul took his own sword and fell upon it. (ESV)

text: Who was Hannah's rival wife, who provoked her?
verseText: He had two wives. The name of the one was Hannah, and the name of the other, Peninnah. And Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children... And her rival used to provoke her grievously to irritate her, because the LORD had closed her womb. (ESV)

text: What specific sin were Eli's sons guilty of regarding the sacrifices?
options: Taking the best parts of the meat before it was boiled/burned for God
verseText: The custom of the priests with the people was that when any man offered sacrifice, the priest's servant would come... with a three-pronged fork... and thrust it into the pan... All that the fork brought up the priest would take for himself... Thus the sin of the young men was very great in the sight of the LORD, for the men treated the offering of the LORD with contempt. (ESV)

text: What message did the young Samuel deliver to Eli from God?
options: Judgment against Eli's house because of his sons' wickedness
verseText: And I declare to him that I am about to punish his house forever, for the iniquity that he knew, because his sons were blaspheming God, and he did not restrain them. Therefore I swear to the house of Eli that the iniquity of Eli's house shall not be atoned for by sacrifice or offering forever. (ESV)

text: What was the name given to Phinehas's son, born just after the Ark was captured?
verseText: And she named the child Ichabod, saying, 'The glory has departed from Israel!' because the ark of God had been captured and because of her father-in-law and her husband. (ESV)

text: Which Philistine cities suffered plagues because of the Ark?
verseText: When the Philistines captured the ark of God, they brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod... So they sent and gathered together all the lords of the Philistines and said, 'Send away the ark of the God of Israel... to Gath.'... So they sent the ark of God to Ekron. (ESV)

text: What guilt offering did the Philistines send back with the Ark?
options: Five golden tumors and five golden mice
verseText: They said, 'What is the guilt offering that we shall return to him?' They answered, 'Five golden tumors and five golden mice, according to the number of the lords of the Philistines...' (ESV)

text: To which Israelite town did the Ark first return?
verseText: Now the people of Beth-shemesh were reaping their wheat harvest in the valley. And when they lifted up their eyes and saw the ark, they rejoiced to see it. (ESV)

text: Why were many men of Beth-shemesh struck down after the Ark's return?
verseText: And he struck some of the men of Beth-shemesh, because they looked upon the ark of the LORD. He struck seventy men of them, and the people mourned because the LORD had struck the people with a great blow. (ESV) [Note: Some manuscripts read '50,070 men']

text: Where was the Ark kept for twenty years after leaving Beth-shemesh?
options: Kiriath-jearim, in the house of Abinadab
verseText: And the men of Kiriath-jearim came and took up the ark of the LORD and brought it to the house of Abinadab on the hill. And they consecrated his son Eleazar to have charge of the ark of the LORD. From the day that the ark was lodged at Kiriath-jearim, a long time passed, some twenty years... (ESV)

text: What memorial stone did Samuel set up after defeating the Philistines at Mizpah?
verseText: Then Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen and called its name Ebenezer; for he said, 'Till now the LORD has helped us.' (ESV)

text: What does 'Ebenezer' mean?
verseText: ...called its name Ebenezer; for he said, 'Till now the LORD has helped us.' (ESV)

text: What warning did Samuel give the Israelites about having a king?
options: The king would take their sons, daughters, fields, and taxes
The king would lead them into idolatry
The king would make treaties with enemies
verseText: He said, 'These will be the ways of the king who will reign over you: he will take your sons... he will take your daughters... He will take the best of your fields... He will take the tenth of your grain...' (ESV)

text: What was Saul doing when Samuel first met him?
options: Looking for his father's lost donkeys
verseText: Now the donkeys of Kish, the father of Saul, were lost. So Kish said to Saul his son, 'Take one of the young men with you, and arise, go and look for the donkeys.' (ESV)

text: How was Saul publicly chosen as king?
verseText: Now Samuel brought all the tribes of Israel near, and the tribe of Benjamin was taken by lot... And Saul the son of Kish was taken by lot. (ESV)

text: Which city did Saul rescue from the Ammonites, confirming his kingship?
verseText: Then Nahash the Ammonite went up and besieged Jabesh-gilead... And on the morrow Saul put the people in three companies. And they came into the midst of the camp in the morning watch and struck down the Ammonites until the heat of the day. (ESV)

text: What rash oath did Saul make during a battle that endangered Jonathan?
options: Cursed anyone who ate food before evening
Vowed to sacrifice the first person he met
Promised riches to the bravest soldier
verseText: And the men of Israel had been hard pressed that day, so Saul had laid an oath on the people, saying, 'Cursed be the man who eats food until it is evening and I am avenged on my enemies.' So none of the people had tasted food. (ESV)

text: How did Jonathan unknowingly break Saul's oath?
verseText: But Jonathan had not heard his father charge the people with the oath, so he put out the tip of the staff that was in his hand and dipped it in the honeycomb and put his hand to his mouth, and his eyes became bright. (ESV)

text: What specific command from God did Saul disobey regarding the Amalekites?
options: He spared King Agag and the best livestock instead of destroying everything
He made a treaty with them
verseText: Now go and strike Amalek and devote to destruction all that they have. Do not spare them... But Saul and the people spared Agag and the best of the sheep and of the oxen and of the fattened calves and the lambs, and all that was good, and would not utterly destroy them. (ESV)

text: What famous statement did Samuel make to Saul about obedience?
options: 'The LORD sees not as man sees'
verseText: And Samuel said, 'Has the LORD as great delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the LORD? Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to listen than the fat of rams.' (ESV)

text: What did God tell Samuel when Samuel looked at David's older brother Eliab?
options: 'The LORD sees not as man sees; man looks on the outward appearance, but the LORD looks on the heart.'
verseText: But the LORD said to Samuel, 'Do not look on his appearance or on the height of his stature, because I have rejected him. For the LORD sees not as man sees: man looks on the outward appearance, but the LORD looks on the heart.' (ESV)

text: What was David's job when Samuel came to anoint him?
verseText: Then Samuel said to Jesse, 'Are all your sons here?' And he said, 'There remains yet the youngest, but behold, he is keeping the sheep.' (ESV)

text: What did David say was his qualification for fighting Goliath?
options: He had killed a lion and a bear while protecting sheep
He was taller than his brothers
verseText: But David said to Saul, 'Your servant used to keep sheep for his father. And when there came a lion, or a bear, and took a lamb from the flock, I went after him and struck him and delivered it out of his mouth... Your servant has struck down both lions and bears, and this uncircumcised Philistine shall be like one of them...' (ESV)

text: What did David do with Goliath's head and armor?
options: Took the head to Jerusalem, put the armor in his tent
verseText: And David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem, but he put his armor in his tent. (ESV)

text: How did Michal save David from Saul's messengers?
options: Let him down through a window and put an idol in his bed
Hid him in a secret room
verseText: So Michal let David down through the window, and he fled away and escaped. Michal took an image and laid it on the bed and put a pillow of goats' hair at its head and covered it with the clothes. (ESV)

text: Who was Doeg the Edomite?
options: Saul's chief herdsman who reported Ahimelech helping David and killed the priests
verseText: Now a certain man of the servants of Saul was there that day, detained before the LORD. His name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of Saul's herdsmen... Then Doeg the Edomite answered... 'I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech...' Then the king said to Doeg, 'You turn and strike the priests.' And Doeg the Edomite turned and struck down the priests... (ESV)

text: Which priest escaped the massacre at Nob and joined David?
verseText: But one of the sons of Ahimelech the son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled after David. (ESV)

text: What city did David save from the Philistines while fleeing Saul?
verseText: And David and his men went to Keilah and fought with the Philistines and brought away their livestock and struck them with a great blow. So David saved the inhabitants of Keilah. (ESV)

text: Where did David cut off the corner of Saul's robe?
verseText: And he came to the sheepfolds by the way, where there was a cave, and Saul went in to relieve himself. Now David and his men were sitting in the innermost parts of the cave... Then David arose and stealthily cut off a corner of Saul's robe. (ESV)

text: Who was Abigail?
options: Nabal's wise wife who later married David
verseText: The name of the man was Nabal, and the name of his wife Abigail. The woman was discerning and beautiful, but the man was harsh and badly behaved... (ESV)

text: How did Nabal die?
options: His heart 'died within him' and he became like a stone after hearing what Abigail did, then died 10 days later
verseText: In the morning, when the wine had gone out of Nabal, his wife told him these things, and his heart died within him, and he became as a stone. And about ten days later the LORD struck Nabal, and he died. (ESV)

text: What items did David and Abishai take from Saul's camp while he slept?
verseText: So David took the spear and the jar of water from Saul's head, and they went away. No man saw it or knew it, nor did anyone awake, for they were all asleep, because a deep sleep from the LORD had fallen upon them. (ESV)

text: Who was Abner?
verseText: The name of Saul's wife was Ahinoam the daughter of Ahimaaz. And the name of the commander of his army was Abner the son of Ner, Saul's uncle. (ESV)

text: To which Philistine king did David flee and pretend to be insane?
verseText: And David rose and fled that day from Saul and went to Achish the king of Gath... So he changed his behavior before them and pretended to be insane in their hands and made marks on the doors of the gate and let his spittle run down his beard. (ESV)

text: What town did King Achish give to David?
verseText: So Achish gave him Ziklag that day. Therefore Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah to this day. (ESV)

text: Whom did Saul consult before his final battle because God wouldn't answer him?
verseText: Then Saul said to his servants, 'Seek out for me a woman who is a medium, that I may go to her and inquire of her.' And his servants said to him, 'Behold, there is a medium at En-dor.' (ESV)

text: Whose spirit did the medium of Endor supposedly bring up for Saul?
verseText: He said to her, 'What is his appearance?' And she said, 'An old man is coming up, and he is wrapped in a robe.' And Saul knew that it was Samuel... (ESV)

text: What devastating event happened at Ziklag while David and his men were away with the Philistines?
options: The Amalekites raided it, burned it, and took the women and children captive
verseText: Now when David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had made a raid against the Negeb and against Ziklag. They had overcome Ziklag and burned it with fire and taken captive the women and all who were in it, both small and great. (ESV)

text: How did David decide whether to pursue the Amalekites who raided Ziklag?
options: Inquired of the LORD using the ephod
verseText: And David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, 'Bring me the ephod.' So Abiathar brought the ephod to David. And David inquired of the LORD, 'Shall I pursue after this band? Shall I overtake them?' He answered him, 'Pursue, for you shall surely overtake and shall surely rescue.' (ESV)

text: What principle did David establish regarding the spoils recovered from the Amalekites?
options: Those who stayed behind guarding supplies shared equally with those who fought
The spoils were given to the priests
verseText: Who would listen to you in this matter? For as his share is who goes down into the battle, so shall his share be who stays by the baggage. They shall share alike. (ESV)

text: Which sons of Saul died with him in the battle against the Philistines?
verseText: And the Philistines overtook Saul and his sons, and the Philistines struck down Jonathan and Abinadab and Malchi-shua, the sons of Saul. (ESV)

text: Where did the Philistines fasten the bodies of Saul and his sons?
verseText: They put his armor in the temple of Ashtaroth, and they fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan. (ESV)

text: Who retrieved the bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Beth-shan?
verseText: But when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul, all the valiant men arose and went all night and took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan... (ESV)

text: What does Hannah's song (1 Samuel 2:1-10) primarily celebrate?
options: God's reversal of fortunes (exalting the humble, humbling the proud) and His sovereignty
verseText: The bows of the mighty are broken, but the feeble bind on strength... The LORD makes poor and makes rich; he brings low and he exalts. He raises up the poor from the dust; he lifts the needy from the ash heap to make them sit with princes... (ESV)

text: The prophecy against Eli's house mentions a future 'faithful priest'. Who is this often understood to prefigure?
verseText: And I will raise up for myself a faithful priest, who shall do according to what is in my heart and in my mind. And I will build him a sure house, and he shall go in and out before my anointed forever. (ESV) [Historically linked to Zadok replacing Abiathar, theologically to Christ]

text: What is the significance of the phrase 'the word of the LORD was rare in those days; there was no frequent vision'?
options: Highlights the spiritual decline under Eli and the significance of God speaking to Samuel
verseText: Now the boy Samuel was ministering to the LORD in the presence of Eli. And the word of the LORD was rare in those days; there was no frequent vision. (ESV)

text: Why did the Israelites bring the Ark of the Covenant into battle against the Philistines?
options: As a superstitious attempt to force God's hand and guarantee victory
verseText: And when the troops came to the camp, the elders of Israel said, 'Why has the LORD defeated us today before the Philistines? Let us bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD here from Shiloh, that it may come among us and save us from the power of our enemies.' (ESV) [Shows misplaced faith in the object]

text: What is the likely significance of the golden mice sent back by the Philistines?
options: Mice were part of the plague accompanying the tumors (possibly bubonic plague)
verseText: 'Five golden tumors and five golden mice... for the same plague was on all of you and on your lords. So you must make images of your tumors and images of your mice that ravage the land...' (ESV)

text: The route taken by the cows pulling the Ark (straight to Beth-shemesh without straying) signified what?
options: That the plague was indeed from the God of Israel, not chance
verseText: 'And watch: if it goes up on the way to its own land, to Beth-shemesh, then it is he who has done us this great harm, but if not, then we shall know that it is not his hand that struck us; it happened to us by coincidence.'... And the cows went straight in the direction of Beth-shemesh... (ESV)

text: Samuel's role combined which three leadership offices?
verseText: And all Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew that Samuel was established as a prophet of the LORD. (3:20) ...And Samuel judged the people of Israel at Mizpah. (7:6) ...Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life. (7:15) [Implicit priestly actions like sacrifice/intercession] (ESV)

text: What theological problem did Israel's request for a king 'like all the nations' present?
options: It was a rejection of the LORD as their true King
They didn't specify the right kind of king
They asked Samuel instead of God directly
verseText: And the LORD said to Samuel, 'Obey the voice of the people in all that they say to you, for they have not rejected you, but they have rejected me from being king over them.' (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Saul hiding among the baggage during his selection?
options: Shows initial reluctance/humility, or perhaps fear/unworthiness
He was trying to avoid being king
verseText: So they inquired again of the LORD, 'Is there a man still to come?' and the LORD said, 'Behold, he has hidden himself among the baggage.' (ESV)

text: What act by Jonathan initiated the battle against the Philistines at Michmash Pass?
options: He and his armor bearer attacked a Philistine garrison alone
verseText: Jonathan said to the young man who carried his armor, 'Come, let us go over to the garrison of these uncircumcised. It may be that the LORD will work for us...' Then Jonathan climbed up on his hands and feet, and his armor-bearer after him. And they fell before Jonathan, and his armor-bearer killed them after him. (ESV)

text: What natural event assisted Jonathan's attack at Michmash?
options: An earthquake that caused panic in the Philistine camp
verseText: And there was a panic in the camp, in the field, and among all the people. The garrison and even the raiders trembled, the earth quaked, and it became a very great panic. (ESV)

text: Why was Saul ultimately rejected by God as king?
options: Disobedience to God's specific commands (sacrifice, Amalekites), showing a lack of submission
verseText: For rebellion is as the sin of divination, and presumption is as iniquity and idolatry. Because you have rejected the word of the LORD, he has also rejected you from being king... And Samuel said to Saul, 'I will not return with you. For you have rejected the word of the LORD, and the LORD has rejected you from being king over Israel.' (ESV)

text: What does the 'harmful spirit from the LORD' that tormented Saul likely signify?
options: A disposition allowed/sent by God involving distress, paranoia, or depression, possibly as judgment
verseText: Now the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul, and a harmful spirit from the LORD tormented him. (ESV) [Theological interpretation varies, but linked to God's judgment]

text: What is the significance of the covenant made between David and Jonathan?
options: Demonstrates selfless love, loyalty transcending family/political ties, and recognition of God's choice of David
verseText: Then Jonathan made a covenant with David, because he loved him as his own soul. And Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that was on him and gave it to David, and his armor, and even his sword and his bow and his belt. (ESV)

text: What was the 'bride price' Saul demanded from David for Michal?
options: One hundred Philistine foreskins (David brought two hundred)
verseText: Then Saul said, 'Thus shall you say to David, "The king desires no bride-price except a hundred foreskins of the Philistines, that he may be avenged of the king's enemies."'... David arose and went... and killed two hundred of the Philistines. And David brought their foreskins... And Saul gave him his daughter Michal for a wife. (ESV) [Saul hoped David would be killed]

text: What does David's feigned madness in Gath reveal about his situation?
options: His desperation and vulnerability while fleeing Saul, forcing him to rely on cunning
He was genuinely losing his mind
verseText: And David took these words to heart and was much afraid of Achish the king of Gath. So he changed his behavior before them and pretended to be insane in their hands... (ESV)

text: Who gathered to David at the cave of Adullam?
options: His family and those who were distressed, in debt, or discontented
verseText: David departed from there and escaped to the cave of Adullam. And when his brothers and all his father's house heard it, they went down there to him. And everyone who was in distress, and everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was bitter in soul, gathered to him. And he became captain over them. And there were with him about four hundred men. (ESV)

text: What principle does David demonstrate by refusing to kill Saul, God's anointed?
options: Respect for God's chosen authority, even when flawed, and trust in God's timing for justice
A desire to win Saul's favor
verseText: He said to his men, 'The LORD forbid that I should do this thing to my lord, the LORD's anointed, to put out my hand against him, seeing he is the LORD's anointed.' (ESV)

text: How does Abigail's intervention with David contrast with Nabal's foolishness?
options: Her wisdom, humility, and appeal to David's righteousness prevent bloodshed, unlike Nabal's arrogance
verseText: Then Abigail made haste and took two hundred loaves... and went after the servants of David... And David said to Abigail, 'Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who sent you this day to meet me! Blessed be your discretion, and blessed be you, who have kept me this day from bloodguilt...' (ESV)

text: Why did the Philistine commanders distrust David and refuse to let him fight with them against Israel?
options: They feared he would turn against them in battle to regain Saul's favor
They knew he was anointed king
verseText: But the commanders of the Philistines were angry with him. And the commanders of the Philistines said to him, 'Send the man back... He shall not go down with us to battle, lest in the battle he become an adversary to us. For how could this fellow reconcile himself to his lord? Would it not be with the heads of the men here? Is not this David...?' (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Saul seeking a medium, an act explicitly forbidden by the Law?
options: Shows his complete desperation, rejection of God's ways, and the finality of God's judgment against him
He didn't know it was forbidden
The medium was secretly a prophetess
verseText: And when Saul inquired of the LORD, the LORD did not answer him... Then Saul said to his servants, 'Seek out for me a woman who is a medium...' Do not turn to mediums or necromancers; do not seek them out, and so make yourselves unclean by them: I am the LORD your God. (Lev 19:31) (ESV)

text: What message did the spirit (appearing as Samuel) give Saul through the medium?
options: Israel would be defeated, and Saul and his sons would die the next day
verseText: Moreover, the LORD will give Israel also with you into the hand of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons shall be with me. The LORD will give the army of Israel also into the hand of the Philistines. (ESV)

text: Who was the Egyptian man found by David's men in the Negeb?
options: A servant of an Amalekite who raided Ziklag, left behind when sick
verseText: They found an Egyptian in the open country and brought him to David... And David said to him, 'To whom do you belong? And where are you from?' He said, 'I am a young man of Egypt, servant to an Amalekite, and my master left me behind because I fell sick three days ago.' (ESV)

text: What does the name 'Ichabod' mean?
options: No glory / The glory has departed
verseText: And she named the child Ichabod, saying, 'The glory has departed from Israel!' (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Samuel hewing Agag in pieces?
options: Completing God's judgment that Saul failed to execute
verseText: Then Samuel said, 'Bring here to me Agag the king of the Amalekites.'... And Samuel said, 'As your sword has made women childless, so shall your mother be childless among women.' And Samuel hacked Agag to pieces before the LORD in Gilgal. (ESV)

text: How does David's lament over Saul and Jonathan (1 Samuel 1:17-27) portray his character?
options: Shows his capacity for grief, loyalty, and honor, even for his enemy
verseText: And David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and Jonathan his son... 'Saul and Jonathan, beloved and lovely! In life and in death they were not divided...' 'I am distressed for you, my brother Jonathan; very pleasant have you been to me; your love to me was extraordinary...' (ESV) [Note: Lament is in 2 Samuel 1]

text: What is the 'Song of the Bow'?
options: David's lament over Saul and Jonathan
verseText: And he said it should be taught to the people of Judah; behold, it is written in the Book of Jashar. He said: [The lament follows] (ESV) [Note: Lament is in 2 Samuel 1, referred to as 'The Bow']

text: What role does the 'Spirit of the LORD' play in 1 Samuel, particularly regarding Saul and David?
options: Empowers for leadership/prophecy, departs from Saul, rushes upon David
Is given to all Israelites equally
verseText: ...the Spirit of God rushed upon him [Saul], and he prophesied among them. (10:10) Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him [David]... And the Spirit of the LORD rushed upon David from that day forward... Now the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul... (16:13-14) (ESV)

text: What is the significance of Nob being a city of priests?
options: It housed the Tabernacle temporarily and was a major religious center before Jerusalem
It was the only city Levites could live in
It was where kings were anointed
verseText: Then David came to Nob to Ahimelech the priest... And Nob, the city of the priests, he put to the sword; both men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep, he put to the sword. (ESV)

text: How does the narrative contrast Saul's leadership failures with David's successes and reliance on God?
options: Saul acts impulsively/disobediently, fears men; David inquires of God, shows restraint/faith
verseText: [Multiple examples throughout the book contrasting Saul's fear/disobedience (e.g., 13:12, 15:24) with David's inquiry/trust (e.g., 23:2, 4, 30:8) and restraint (24:6, 26:9)] (ESV)
